page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual garage placement

Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.

How to determine if contextual garage placement applies (using Fig 32 below as an example)
Note:
• If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots with in 600' or the 10 lots closest to the subject lot
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces

[Start of flowchart text]

[Box 1]
Exclude the following types of lots:
• Flag lot (C)
• Multi-family use of 3+ units (G)
• Corner lots (A & H)

The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.

Note:
• If block more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' or 10 closest lots.
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the garage faces

[Box 2]
Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories:

1. Front-half pattern lots
  • lots with garage in front half of the lot (F)

2. Rear-half pattern lots
  • lots with garage in the rear half of the lot (B & D) and
  • lots with no garage (E) (counts as a rear-pattern lot)

Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.

[Box 3]
Front half

[Box 4]
Rear half

[Box 5]
The contextual-garage placement regulation DOES apply. Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.

[End of flowchart text]

Fig 32 Example of a block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies

[Text within Figure 32]

visual_elements.description: A flowchart explaining the decision-making process for contextual garage placement. It starts with a box titled 'Exclude the following types of lots', which points to a second box titled 'Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories'. This second box has two outputs: '1. Front-half pattern lots' and '2. Rear-half pattern lots'. These outputs are visually represented by arrows pointing to boxes labeled 'Front half' and 'Rear half' respectively. An arrow from the 'Rear half' box points to a final conclusion box stating that the regulation applies and the garage must be placed in the rear half of the lot.

Figure 32 is a top-down plan view of a residential block with eight lots, labeled A through H. It illustrates the rules described in the text. Lots A, C, and H are shown crossed out with a large 'X', indicating they are excluded from the determination. Lot A and H are corner lots. Lot C is a flag lot. Lot G is shown with 'Multiple garages'. Lot F is identified as the 'Subject House' and has a garage in the front half. Lots B and D have garages in the rear half. Lot E has a house but no garage. The lots are arranged along a street or alleyway depicted at the very bottom of the figure.

subheadings: Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.

sections: Exclude the following types of lots

additional_notes: The page is clean and appears to be a digital document or a high-quality photocopy.
There are two 'Note:' sections with slightly different wording. The first one, at the top of the page, contains 'with in'. The second one, within the flowchart, contains 'within'.
The page number '37' is located at the bottom right corner.
cross_references: '(using Fig 32 below as an example)' - Refers to the figure on the same page.
References to lots (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H) in the text correspond to the labels in Figure 32.
